title: Stable isotopes in avian research: a step by step protocol to feather sample preparation for stable isotope analysis of carbon (δ13C), nitrogen (δ15N), and hydrogen (δ2H). Version 1.1
title_html: Stable isotopes in avian research: a step by step protocol to feather sample preparation for stable isotope analysis of carbon (δ13C), nitrogen (δ15N), and hydrogen (δ2H). Version 1.1

authors.name: Brian Chew
authors.affiliation: Corix Plains Institute, University of Oklahoma, Five Partners Place, 201 Stephenson Parkway, Norman, OK 73019, USA; Oklahoma Biological Survey, University of Oklahoma, 111 East Chesapeake Street, SC Building 134, Norman, OK 73019, USA

authors.name: Jeff Kelly
authors.affiliation: Corix Plains Institute, University of Oklahoma, Five Partners Place, 201 Stephenson Parkway, Norman, OK 73019, USA; Oklahoma Biological Survey, University of Oklahoma, 111 East Chesapeake Street, SC Building 134, Norman, OK 73019, USA; Department of Biology, University of Oklahoma, 730 Van Vleet Oval, Norman, OK 73019, USA

authors.name: Andrea Contina
authors.affiliation: University of Colorado Denver, Department of Integrative Biology, Science Building 2074, Denver, CO

source.title: Preparation of Cleaning Solution: 2:1 Chloroform Methanol Solution

source.description: Under fume hood, pour 100mL chloroform into clean 250 mL beaker.

source.title: Preparation of Cleaning Solution: 2:1 Chloroform Methanol Solution

source.description: Pour 50mL methanol into beaker.

source.title: Preparation of Cleaning Solution: 2:1 Chloroform Methanol Solution

source.description: Stir contents with a stir rod, or carefully swirl contents of container under fume hood to mix contents.

source.title: Preparation of Cleaning Solution: 2:1 Chloroform Methanol Solution

source.description: If desired for repeated use, pour 2:1 chloroform methanol solution into at least 250mL container with sealable, non-plastic lid.

source.title: Preparation of Cleaning Solutions: 30:1 Deionized Water Detergent Solution

source.description: In clean 250mL beaker, pour 150mL deionized water, and 5mL detergent.

source.title: Preparation of Cleaning Solutions: 30:1 Deionized Water Detergent Solution

source.description: Gently swirl content of container.

source.title: Preparation of Cleaning Solutions: 30:1 Deionized Water Detergent Solution

source.description: Avoid agitating solution in any manner which might generate bubbles.

source.title: Preparation of Cleaning Solutions: 30:1 Deionized Water Detergent Solution

source.description: Mark beaker DETERGENT.

source.title: Preparation of Cleaning Solutions: 30:1 Deionized Water Detergent Solution

source.description: Into three clean 250mL beakers, pour 200mL deionized water each.

source.title: Preparation of Cleaning Solutions: 30:1 Deionized Water Detergent Solution

source.description: Mark Beakers 1, 2, and 3.

source.title: Preparation of Cleaning Solutions: 30:1 Deionized Water Detergent Solution

source.description: Place beakers in order DETERGENT, 1, 2, 3. Feathers will be cleaned in this order to avoid final prepared feather being contaminated with detergent.

source.title: Preparing of Feathers

source.description: Using calipers, measure the length of the feather, starting from the tip of the quill (calamus) to the end of the rachis or farthest barb. Record the weight of the feather with balance.

source.title: Preparing of Feathers

source.description: Using a razor that has been cleaned with ethanol, cut off the calamus of the feather as indicated below:

source.title: Preparing of Feathers

source.description: It is useful to use one hand to hold down the feather by placing the gloved base of your hand against the end of the feather and holding the calamus with forceps when cutting the calamus, this prevents the calamus from being lost. (technique pictured above)

source.title: Preparing of Feathers

source.description: The calamus is removed to later acquire DNA from the feather.

source.title: Preparing of Feathers

source.description: Place separated calamus into marked and clean paper envelope, to absorb humidity, and seal envelope with adhesive to ensure calamus is retained. Label the clean envelope with banding ID number, location, species, sex, and date of collection.

source.title: Preparing of Feathers

source.description: With clean paper towels, prepare in advance a drying “bed” for feathers by layering the paper towels over one another.

source.title: Preparing of Feathers

source.description: Using forceps, hold the rachis of the feather so that the feather is perpendicular to the forceps. Under a fume hood, dip the feather into a 2:1 (chloroform methanol) solution.

source.title: Preparing of Feathers

source.description: Agitate the feather to make stirring motions with the feather for 30 seconds.

source.title: Preparing of Feathers

source.description: After each feather has been washed in 2:1 (chloroform methanol) solution, place each feather on dry cloth or paper towel, next to clean envelopes showing feather details and individual IDs.

source.title: Preparing of Feathers

source.description: Allow feather to dry for 24-36 hours or until completely dry.

source.title: Preparing of Feathers

source.description: Please note: 24-36 hours was at room temperature of 26C near the room's heating system. This may have reduced drying time in our lab.

source.title: Preparing of Feathers

source.description: With clean forceps, pick up each feather from the drying bed and dip into solution of 30:1 water to detergent (prepared from Steps 5-10 above.)

source.title: Preparing of Feathers

source.description: Agitate each feather for 30 seconds to ensure thorough cleaning.

source.title: Preparing of Feathers

source.description: After 30 seconds of cleaning remove the feather from 30:1 water to detergent solution with forceps, and place each feather into the container of deionized water (first beaker, labelled "1.")

source.title: Preparing of Feathers

source.description: Agitate feather for 30 seconds.

source.title: Preparing of Feathers

source.description: Repeat step 21-22 two additional times with separate beakers of deionized clean water (beakers "2", and "3.")

source.title: Preparing of Feathers

source.description: Note: ensure the order of containers (beakers) is kept the same for every feather to ensure all detergent is removed from each feather.

source.title: Preparing of Feathers

source.description: Place each cleaned feather onto paper towel to dry, and transfer marked envelopes from Step 6 to place adjacent to each feather to keep track of samples.

source.title: Preparing of Feathers

source.description: Ensure every feather is next to its respective envelope (label), and that the placement of each feather relative to its labelled envelope is kept the same for every feather, to ensure the feathers details are not mistaken.

source.title: Preparing of Feathers

source.description: Allow feather to dry for 24-36 hours or until completely dry.

source.title: Preparing of Feathers

source.description: Place each feather into its respective clean labelled envelope, and store cleaned envelopes into separate container.

source.title: Weighing standards for stable isotope analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: Clean three sets of forceps and a spatula with 95% ethanol by staurating a kimwipeTM with ethanol and rubbing all used surfaces of the instrument. Place instrument under lamp or in direct light to evaporate ethanol.

source.title: Weighing standards for stable isotope analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: Using air duster, or similar cleaning product, clear surface of microbalance, and remove any particles from previous uses. Ensure chamber is clean, no residuals remain from previous uses.

source.title: Weighing standards for stable isotope analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: Air duster will remove particles from chamber.

source.title: Weighing standards for stable isotope analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: Using forceps, place a 3.5x5mm silver capsule, open end up, into the center of a microbalance.

source.title: Weighing standards for stable isotope analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: Bent tip forceps are preferred for this step.

source.title: Weighing standards for stable isotope analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: Close microbalance chamber and tare microbalance to empty silver capsule mass.

source.title: Weighing standards for stable isotope analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: With spatula, pick up a very small quantity (as shown in the photo) of BHCO, KHS, or CBS standard.

source.title: Weighing standards for stable isotope analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: REMEMBER: silver capsules are used for hydrogen isotope analysis, tin capsules are used for carbon and nitrogen isotope analysis. Please see Table 1 below for further details on standards and weights for different isotopes. This is crucial!

source.title: Weighing standards for stable isotope analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: Open microbalance chamber, and hold spatula with standard over open capsule. Use second pair of forceps to push small quantities of standard off of the end of the spatula into the capsule.

source.title: Weighing standards for stable isotope analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: Remove spatula and forceps from balance chamber, and close draft shield doors.

source.title: Weighing standards for stable isotope analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: If mass of standard is below required standard mass, repeat steps 32-33, else proceed to step 35.

source.title: Weighing standards for stable isotope analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: If mass of standard is above required mass, use bent tip forcepts to hold capsule, and second pair of forceps to remove tiny excess of standard and place into waste receptacle.

source.title: Weighing standards for stable isotope analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: Once desired mass is achieved, record mass on data sheet (see below for data sheet template), and use bent tip forceps to remove capsule from microbalance. Place capsule on clean flat surface.

source.title: Weighing standards for stable isotope analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: Using the tip of a third pair of forceps, push the opened end of the capsule so it gets closed (sealed), and continue to hold end closed with forceps.

source.title: Weighing standards for stable isotope analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: With a gloved hand very gently squeeze the base of the capsule between thumb and forefinger until capsule is completely flat. If you squeeze too quickly, you might damage the capsule and disperse the standard.

source.title: Weighing standards for stable isotope analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: Using forceps holding the end of the capsule, place the capsule flat end down on a clean, dry surface, and rotate forcepts 180 degrees in the direction of the rest of the capsule, creating a curved section of the capsule in the place of the opening.

source.title: Weighing standards for stable isotope analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: Gently ungrasp the end of capsule with forceps, and regrasp the capsule with the inside of one arm of the forceps on outside of the end of the curved portion of capsule, and the inside portion of the other arm of the forceps on the nearest flat portion of the capsule to the newly formed curved section. Squeeze the forceps to make a fold in the capsule.

source.title: Weighing standards for stable isotope analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: Repeat steps 39 and 40 until capsule is approximately twice the width of the forceps in length. Fold any remaining capsule over the folded portion of the capsule.

source.title: Weighing standards for stable isotope analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: Place the now folded capsule on a flat, clean, dry surface, and place the forceps around the capsule such that the inside of the arms fo the forceps have greater hight than the capsule, and the angle between the capsule sides and the forcep arms is minimized. Squeeze the arms of the forceps gently, to compact the capsule along its width. Make the capsule as round-ish as possible.

source.title: Weighing standards for stable isotope analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: If necessary, rotate the capsule 90 degrees, and repeat step 42. Repeat this step until every oientation of the caspule has been pressed an equal number of times.

source.title: Weighing standards for stable isotope analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: This ensures the capsule maintains a relatively cubic or round-ish shape.

source.title: Weighing standards for stable isotope analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: If necessary, pick up the foceps and place the outside surface of one arm of the forceps onto the topmost surface of the capsule. Press the forceps so the capsule is pressed evenly along its topmost surface.

Repeat steps 43-44 until capsule has relatively smooth surfaces and is cubic or round-ish. There should not be tears in the surface of the capsule or any sections of the capsule that extend out beyond the rest of the cubic or round-ish shape.
If any tearing occurs, or if the capsule is dropped onto an uncleaned surface at any time, place the compromised capsule into a waste receptacle, and restart the process with a fresh capsule.

When the capsule is to the desired dimensions, use a pair of forceps to place the capsule into its designated well on the tray. Record what well the capsule has been placed into (e.g. A6, or C5, etc.) on a data sheet, along with the final weight, sample ID, and any other relavant information.

source.title: Weighing Feather Samples for Stable Isotope Analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: Clean two sets of forceps and a razor blade with 95% ethanol by saturating a kimwipeTM with ethanol and rubbing all used surfaces of the instruments. Place instruments under lamp or another direct light source to evaporate ethanol.

source.title: Weighing Feather Samples for Stable Isotope Analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: Using air duster, or similar cleaning product, clear surface of microbalance.

source.title: Weighing Feather Samples for Stable Isotope Analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: With clean razor blade, cut off a portion of the tip of the now cleaned and dried feather (the point opposite the calamus) to be sampled for stable isotope analysis.

source.title: Weighing Feather Samples for Stable Isotope Analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: The method of cutting is not important, but how the feather is cut should remain consistent between feather samples. We recommend cutting from the rachis, and using the barbs attached to the incised rachis. Note that different sections of the rachis might introduce variation stable isotope values (particularly for longer feathers) and we recommend to be consistent across feather samples with the tip and rachis section being used for analysis.

source.title: Weighing Feather Samples for Stable Isotope Analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: Using forceps, gently separate the clipped part of the rachis and any attached barbs from the rest of the feather.

source.title: Weighing Feather Samples for Stable Isotope Analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: Using clean forceps, place feather on tared balance, and close balance shields.

source.title: Weighing Feather Samples for Stable Isotope Analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: If the feather is above desired mass, use clean razor to cut off an additional portion of the feather. Using same forceps as in the previous step, place the feather on the balance. Repeat as needed until weight is within desired parameters (+/- 10 µg.)

source.title: Weighing Feather Samples for Stable Isotope Analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: If the feather is above desired mass, using same forceps as step 51, remove the feather from balance, and use a clean razor to remove small portions of the sample.

source.title: Weighing Feather Samples for Stable Isotope Analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: If sample is close to desired mass, barbs can be used for finer adjustment of mass, while removal of rachis will produce a larger change in mass.

source.title: Weighing Feather Samples for Stable Isotope Analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: If sample is within desired mass, remove from balance with forceps, and place onto clean surface.

source.title: Weighing Feather Samples for Stable Isotope Analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: Using clean bent forceps, place empty capsule onto balance and tare balance.

source.title: Weighing Feather Samples for Stable Isotope Analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: Remove capsule from balance, with clean forceps, place sample inside the capsule.

source.title: Weighing Feather Samples for Stable Isotope Analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: It may be necessary to separate the feather sample into smaller subsections with a razor in order to fit into capsule.

source.title: Weighing Feather Samples for Stable Isotope Analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: Be careful that portions of the sample are not protruding from the capsule by static electricity.

source.title: Weighing Feather Samples for Stable Isotope Analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: When all portions of sample are inside capsule, use bent forceps to place capsule with sample into balance.

source.title: Weighing Feather Samples for Stable Isotope Analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: If readout of balance does not match original mass, check razor, forceps, and cutting surface for portions of sample that may have been ejected form capsule or that may have adhered to instruments. Use forceps to transfer these sample portions into capsule.

source.title: Weighing Feather Samples for Stable Isotope Analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: Once desired mass is acheived, record mass on data sheet together with sample ID, and use bent tip forceps to remove capsule from microbalance. Place capsule on clean flat surface.

source.title: Weighing Feather Samples for Stable Isotope Analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: Using the tip of a pair of forceps, push the open end of the capsule closed, and continue to hold end closed with forceps.

source.title: Weighing Feather Samples for Stable Isotope Analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: With a gloved hand gently squeeze the base of the capsule between thumb and forefinger until the capsule is flat. Do not damage the capsule.

source.title: Weighing Feather Samples for Stable Isotope Analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: Using forceps, holding the end of the capsule, place the capsule flat end down on a clean, dry surface, and rotate forceps 180 degrees to form a curved section of the capsule.

source.title: Weighing Feather Samples for Stable Isotope Analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: Gently ungrasp end of capsule with forceps, and regrasp capsule with the inside of one arm of the forcep on the end of the curved portion of the capsule, and the inside protion of the other arm of the forcep on the nearest flat portion of the capsule to the newly formed curved section. Squeeze the forceps to make a fold in the capsule.

source.title: Weighing Feather Samples for Stable Isotope Analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: Repeat steps 62 and 63 until capsule is approximately twice the width of the forceps in length. Fold any remaining capsule over the folded portion of the capsule.

source.title: Weighing Feather Samples for Stable Isotope Analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: Using a third pair of forceps, grab one of the ends of the capsule and repeat steps 64 along the width of the capsule until capsule approaches desired shape for analysis.

source.title: Weighing Feather Samples for Stable Isotope Analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: Place now foldd capsule on a flat, clean, dry surface, and place the forceps around the capsule such that the inside of the arms of the forceps have a greater height thtan the capsule, and the angle between the capsule sides and the forceps is a minimum. Squeeze the arms of the forceps gently, to compact the capsule along its width.

source.title: Weighing Feather Samples for Stable Isotope Analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: Rotate the capsule 90 degrees, and repeat step 66.

source.title: Weighing Feather Samples for Stable Isotope Analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: Rotate capsule after every compression fo ensure a relatively cubic or rectangular or round-ish shape.

source.title: Weighing Feather Samples for Stable Isotope Analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: Pick up the forceps and place the outside surface of one arm of the forceps onto the topmost surface of the capsule. Press the forceps so that the capsule is pressed evenly along its topmost surface. See photo above.

source.title: Weighing Feather Samples for Stable Isotope Analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: Repeat steps 67-68 until the capsule has relatively smooth sides, and is cubic or round-ish in shape. There should be no tears in the surface of the capsule.

source.title: Weighing Feather Samples for Stable Isotope Analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description: If tearing occurs, or if the capsule is droppe donto an uncleaned surface at any time, place the compromised capsule into a waste receptacle, and restart the process with a fresh capsule.

source.title: Weighing Feather Samples for Stable Isotope Analysis (Hydrogen)

source.description:
Once the capsule is completely pressd, pick up the capsule with clean forceps and place the capsule into designated well. Record well position (e.g. A6, or C7, etc.), next to sample weight, sample ID, and tray identification number and species.
REMEMBER: Print this data sheet and always keep it attached to the plastic tray that will be used to transport the samples to the mass-spec lab. Keep track of the samples! IMPORTANT: the sequence of the samples and standards matters, we recommend to follow the examples below.
Example of data sheet for Hydrogen (see Table 1)
Example of data sheet for Carbon and Nitrogen (see Table 1)

description:
Summary
Using a 2:1 chloroform methanol solution and Versatm detergent diluted with deionized water we cleaned feather samples of oil/debris for stable isotope analysis of carbon (δ13C), nitrogen (δ15N), and hydrogen (δ2H). Prepared samples were then measured, cut, and packaged in tin or silver capsules for analysis of carbon(δ13C) and nitrogen(δ15N) or hydrogen(δ2H), respectively. We aim to standardize the laboratory procedure across institutions and research groups focused on avian ecology and conservation and to improve result accuracy and reproducibility.
Background
Stable isotope analysis of relatively abundant elements such as carbon (δ13C), nitrogen (δ15N), and hydrogen (δ2H) have been widely implemented, particularly over the past two decades, in ecology, conservation, and forensic studies (Vander Zanden et al. 2018.). For example, stable isotope analyses of biological tissues can reveal useful information on diet, trophic level interactions, and large scale animal movements (Bridge et al. 2011; Contina et al. 2013; Zenzal et al. 2018). However, laboratory sample preparation for stable isotope studies requires a standardized protocol to ensure accuracy and repeatability of the results (Paritte and Kelly 2009).
Corresponding author: andrea.contina@ucdenver.edu
Useful references:
Zenzal T.J. et al. 2018. Temporal migration patterns between natal locations of ruby-throated hummingbirds (Archilochus colubris) and their Gulf Coast stopover site. Movement ecology, 6(1), p.2.
Vander Zanden et al. 2018. Application of isoscapes to determine geographic origin of terrestrial wildlife for conservation and management. Biological conservation, 228, pp.268-280.
Contina et al. 2013. Using geologgers to investigate bimodal isotope patterns in Painted Buntings (Passerina ciris). The Auk, 130(2), pp.265-272.
Bridge et al. 2011. Causes of bimodal stable isotope signatures in the feathers of a molt-migrant songbird. Canadian Journal of Zoology, 89(10), pp.951-959.
Paritte and Kelly 2009. Effect of cleaning regime on stable-isotope ratios of feathers in Japanese Quail (Coturnix japonica). The Auk, 126(1), pp.165-174.
